an5.240:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an5.240:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a resident mendicant with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.240:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an5.240:1.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.240:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an5.240:2.1.eng: A resident mendicant with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.240:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato āvāsiko bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.240:2.8.eng: A resident mendicant with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.241:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of bad conduct.

an5.241:1.4.eng: After examination, sensible people criticize you.

an5.241:1.6.eng: You feel lost when you die.

an5.241:1.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an5.241:1.7.eng: And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.241:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā duccarite.
an5.241:1.8.eng: These are the five drawbacks of bad conduct.

an5.241:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of good conduct.

an5.241:2.4.eng: After examination, sensible people praise you.

an5.241:2.6.eng: You don’t feel lost when you die.

an5.241:2.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.241:2.7.eng: When your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.241:2.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā sucarite”ti.
an5.241:2.8.eng: These are the five benefits of good conduct.”

an5.242:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks in bad bodily conduct … benefits in good bodily conduct …”

an5.243:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks in bad verbal conduct … benefits in good verbal conduct …”

an5.244:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks in bad mental conduct … benefits in good mental conduct …”

an5.244:1.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.

an5.244:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā manosucarite”ti.

an5.245:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of bad conduct.

an5.245:1.4.eng: After examination, sensible people criticize you.

an5.245:1.6.eng: You drift away from true teachings.

an5.245:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā duccarite.
an5.245:1.8.eng: These are the five drawbacks of bad conduct.

an5.245:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of good conduct.

an5.245:2.4.eng: After examination, sensible people praise you.

an5.245:2.6.eng: You drift away from untrue teachings.

an5.245:2.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā sucarite”ti.
an5.245:2.8.eng: These are the five benefits of good conduct.”

an5.246:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks in bad bodily conduct … benefits in good bodily conduct …”

an5.247:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks in bad verbal conduct … benefits in good verbal conduct …”

an5.248:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks in bad mental conduct … benefits in good mental conduct …”

an5.248:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā manosucarite”ti.

an5.249:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks to a charnel ground.

an5.249:1.3.pli: Asuci, duggandhā, sappaṭibhayā, vāḷānaṃ amanussānaṃ āvāso, bahuno janassa ārodanā—
an5.249:1.3.eng: It’s filthy, stinking, frightening, a gathering place for savage monsters, and a weeping place for many people.

an5.249:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā sivathikāya.
an5.249:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of a charnel ground.

an5.249:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcime ādīnavā sivathikūpame puggale.
an5.249:2.1.eng: In the same way there are five drawbacks of an individual like a charnel ground.

an5.249:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo asucinā kāyakammena samannāgato hoti;
an5.249:2.3.eng: To start with, an individual has filthy conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an5.249:2.6.eng: This is how they’re filthy, I say.

an5.249:2.7.eng: That individual is just as filthy as a charnel ground.

an5.249:3.1.pli: Tassa asucinā kāyakammena samannāgatassa, asucinā vacīkammena samannāgatassa, asucinā manokammena samannāgatassa pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
an5.249:3.1.eng: Because of their filthy conduct, they get a bad reputation.

an5.249:3.2.eng: This is how they’re stinky, I say.

an5.249:3.3.eng: That individual is just as stinky as a charnel ground.

an5.249:4.1.pli: Tamenaṃ asucinā kāyakammena samannāgataṃ, asucinā vacīkammena samannāgataṃ, asucinā manokammena samannāgataṃ pesalā sabrahmacārī ārakā parivajjanti.
an5.249:4.1.eng: Because of their filthy conduct, good-hearted spiritual companions avoid them from afar.

an5.249:4.2.eng: That’s how they’re frightening, I say.

an5.249:4.3.eng: That individual is just as frightening as a charnel ground.

an5.249:5.1.pli: So asucinā kāyakammena samannāgato, asucinā vacīkammena samannāgato, asucinā manokammena samannāgato sabhāgehi puggalehi saddhiṃ saṃvasati.
an5.249:5.1.eng: Because of their filthy conduct, they live together with individuals of a similar character.

an5.249:5.2.eng: This is how they gather with savage monsters, I say.

an5.249:5.3.pli: Seyyathāpi sā, bhikkhave, sivathikā vāḷānaṃ amanussānaṃ āvāso;
an5.249:5.3.eng: That individual is just as much a gathering place of savage monsters as a charnel ground.

an5.249:6.1.pli: Tamenaṃ asucinā kāyakammena samannāgataṃ, asucinā vacīkammena samannāgataṃ, asucinā manokammena samannāgataṃ pesalā sabrahmacārī disvā khīyadhammaṃ āpajjanti:
an5.249:6.1.eng: Because of their filthy conduct, when good-hearted spiritual companions see them they complain:

an5.249:6.2.pli: ‘aho vata no dukkhaṃ ye mayaṃ evarūpehi puggalehi saddhiṃ saṃvasāmā’ti.
an5.249:6.2.eng: ‘Oh, it’s so painful for us to have to live together with such as these.’

an5.249:6.3.eng: This is how there’s weeping, I say.

an5.249:6.4.pli: Seyyathāpi sā, bhikkhave, sivathikā bahuno janassa ārodanā;
an5.249:6.4.eng: This person is just as much a weeping place for many people as a charnel ground.

an5.249:6.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā sivathikūpame puggale”ti.
an5.249:6.6.eng: These are the five drawbacks of an individual like a charnel ground.”

an5.25:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi anuggahitā sammādiṭṭhi cetovimuttiphalā ca hoti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca hoti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca.
an5.25:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when right view is supported by five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.

an5.25:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi sīlānuggahitā ca hoti, sutānuggahitā ca hoti, sākacchānuggahitā ca hoti, samathānuggahitā ca hoti, vipassanānuggahitā ca hoti.
an5.25:2.2.eng: It’s when right view is supported by ethics, learning, discussion, serenity, and discernment.

an5.25:2.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi anuggahitā sammādiṭṭhi cetovimuttiphalā ca hoti cetovimuttiphalānisaṃsā ca, paññāvimuttiphalā ca hoti paññāvimuttiphalānisaṃsā cā”ti.
an5.25:2.3.eng: When right view is supported by these five factors it has freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom as its fruit and benefit.”

an5.250:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of placing faith in an individual.

an5.250:1.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, puggale puggalo abhippasanno hoti, so tathārūpaṃ āpattiṃ āpanno hoti yathārūpāya āpattiyā saṅgho ukkhipati.
an5.250:1.3.eng: The individual to whom an individual is devoted falls into an offense such that the Saṅgha suspends them.

an5.250:1.5.pli: ‘yo kho myāyaṃ puggalo piyo manāpo so saṅghena ukkhitto’ti.
an5.250:1.5.eng: ‘This individual dear and beloved to me has been suspended by the Saṅgha.’

an5.250:1.6.eng: They lose much of their faith in mendicants.

an5.250:1.7.pli: Bhikkhūsu appasādabahulo samāno aññe bhikkhū na bhajati.
an5.250:1.7.eng: So they don’t frequent other mendicants,

an5.250:1.8.pli: Aññe bhikkhū abhajanto saddhammaṃ na suṇāti.
an5.250:1.8.eng: they don’t hear the true teaching,

an5.250:1.9.eng: and they fall away from the true teaching.

an5.250:1.10.eng: This is the first drawback in placing faith in an individual.

an5.250:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ puggale puggalo abhippasanno hoti, so tathārūpaṃ āpattiṃ āpanno hoti yathārūpāya āpattiyā saṅgho ante nisīdāpeti.
an5.250:2.1.eng: Furthermore, the individual to whom an individual is devoted falls into an offense such that the Saṅgha makes them sit at the end of the line. …

an5.250:2.3.pli: ‘yo kho myāyaṃ puggalo piyo manāpo so saṅghena ante nisīdāpito’ti.

an5.250:2.5.pli: Bhikkhūsu appasādabahulo samāno aññe bhikkhū na bhajati.

an5.250:2.6.pli: Aññe bhikkhū abhajanto saddhammaṃ na suṇāti.

an5.250:2.8.eng: This is the second drawback in placing faith in an individual.

an5.250:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, yasmiṃ puggale puggalo abhippasanno hoti, so disāpakkanto hoti …pe… so vibbhanto hoti …pe… so kālaṅkato hoti.
an5.250:3.1.eng: Furthermore, the individual to whom an individual is devoted leaves for another region … disrobes … passes away.

an5.250:3.3.pli: ‘yo kho myāyaṃ puggalo piyo manāpo so kālaṅkato’ti.
an5.250:3.3.eng: ‘This individual dear and beloved to me has passed away.’

an5.250:3.4.eng: So they don’t frequent other mendicants,

an5.250:3.5.pli: Aññe bhikkhū abhajanto saddhammaṃ na suṇāti.
an5.250:3.5.eng: they don’t hear the true teaching,

an5.250:3.6.eng: and they fall away from the true teaching.

an5.250:3.7.eng: This is the fifth drawback in placing faith in an individual.

an5.250:3.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā puggalappasāde”ti.
an5.250:3.8.eng: These are the five drawbacks of placing faith in an individual.”

an5.251:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, ordination should be given by a mendicant with five qualities.

an5.251:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asekhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti;
an5.251:1.3.eng: It’s a mendicant who has the entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics,

an5.251:1.7.eng: and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.251:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabban”ti.
an5.251:1.8.eng: Ordination should be given by a mendicant with these five qualities.”

an5.252:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā nissayo dātabbo.
an5.252:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, dependence should be given by a mendicant with five qualities.

an5.252:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asekhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti …pe… asekhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti.
an5.252:1.3.eng: It’s a mendicant who has the entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.252:1.4.eng: Dependence should be given by a mendicant with these five qualities.”

an5.253:0.3.eng: Who Should Have a Novice as Attendant

an5.253:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo.
an5.253:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a novice should attend on a mendicant with five qualities.

an5.253:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asekhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti; asekhena samādhikkhandhena … asekhena paññākkhandhena … asekhena vimuttikkhandhena … asekhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti.
an5.253:1.3.eng: It’s a mendicant who has the entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.

an5.253:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo”ti.
an5.253:1.4.eng: A novice should attend on a mendicant with these five qualities.”

an5.254:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of stinginess.

an5.254:1.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

an5.254:1.4.eng: These are the five kinds of stinginess.

an5.254:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ macchariyānaṃ etaṃ paṭikuṭṭhaṃ, yadidaṃ dhammamacchariyan”ti.
an5.254:1.5.eng: The most contemptible of these five kinds of stinginess is stinginess with the teaching.”

an5.255:1.1.pli: “Pañcannaṃ, bhikkhave, macchariyānaṃ pahānāya samucchedāya brahmacariyaṃ vussati.
an5.255:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the spiritual life is lived to give up and cut out these five kinds of stinginess.

an5.255:1.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

an5.255:1.4.pli: kulamacchariyassa … lābhamacchariyassa … vaṇṇamacchariyassa … dhammamacchariyassa pahānāya samucchedāya brahmacariyaṃ vussati.

an5.255:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ macchariyānaṃ pahānāya samucchedāya brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti.
an5.255:1.5.eng: The spiritual life is lived to give up and cut out these five kinds of stinginess.”

an5.256:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhamme appahāya abhabbo paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an5.256:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without giving up these five qualities you can’t enter and remain in the first absorption.

an5.256:1.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

an5.256:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhamme appahāya abhabbo paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an5.256:1.4.eng: Without giving up these five qualities you can’t enter and remain in the first absorption.

an5.256:2.1.pli: Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhamme pahāya bhabbo paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharituṃ.
an5.256:2.1.eng: But after giving up these five qualities you can enter and remain in the first absorption.

an5.256:2.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

an5.256:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhamme pahāya bhabbo paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharitun”ti.
an5.256:2.4.eng: After giving up these five qualities you can enter and remain in the first absorption.”

an5.257-263:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhamme appahāya abhabbo dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… abhabbo tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ … abhabbo catutthaṃ jhānaṃ … abhabbo sotāpattiphalaṃ … abhabbo sakadāgāmiphalaṃ … abhabbo anāgāmiphalaṃ … abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an5.257-263:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, without giving up these five qualities you can’t enter and remain in the second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption … or realize the fruit of stream-entry … the fruit of once-return … the fruit of non-return … perfection.

an5.257-263:1.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

an5.257-263:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhamme appahāya abhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an5.257-263:1.4.eng: Without giving up these five qualities you can’t realize perfection.

an5.257-263:2.1.pli: Pañcime, bhikkhave, dhamme pahāya bhabbo dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe… bhabbo tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ … bhabbo catutthaṃ jhānaṃ … bhabbo sotāpattiphalaṃ … bhabbo sakadāgāmiphalaṃ … bhabbo anāgāmiphalaṃ … bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātuṃ.
an5.257-263:2.1.eng: But after giving up these five qualities you can enter and remain in the second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption … and realize the fruit of stream-entry … the fruit of once-return … the fruit of non-return … perfection.

an5.257-263:2.3.eng: Stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

an5.257-263:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhamme pahāya bhabbo arahattaṃ sacchikātun”ti.
an5.257-263:2.4.eng: After giving up these five qualities you can realize perfection.”

an5.26:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, vimuttāyatanāni yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an5.26:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five opportunities for freedom. If a mendicant stays diligent, keen, and resolute at these times, their mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

an5.26:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī.
an5.26:2.2.eng: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.

an5.26:2.3.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tassa bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an5.26:2.3.eng: In whatever way the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to that mendicant, they always feel inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma.

an5.26:2.6.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

an5.26:2.7.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

an5.26:2.8.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an5.26:2.9.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ vimuttāyatanaṃ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an5.26:2.9.eng: This is the first opportunity for freedom. If a mendicant stays diligent, keen, and resolute at this time, their mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

an5.26:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti.
an5.26:3.1.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant. But the mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.

an5.26:3.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an5.26:3.2.eng: In whatever way that mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it, they always feel inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma.

an5.26:3.5.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

an5.26:3.6.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

an5.26:3.7.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an5.26:3.8.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ vimuttāyatanaṃ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an5.26:3.8.eng: This is the second opportunity for freedom. …

an5.26:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti, api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti.
an5.26:4.1.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma. But the mendicant rehearses the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it.

an5.26:4.2.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an5.26:4.2.eng: In whatever way that mendicant rehearses the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it, they always feel inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma.

an5.26:4.5.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

an5.26:4.6.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

an5.26:4.7.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an5.26:4.8.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ vimuttāyatanaṃ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino …pe… yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an5.26:4.8.eng: This is the third opportunity for freedom. …

an5.26:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti;
an5.26:5.1.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma … nor does the mendicant rehearse the teaching.

an5.26:5.2.pli: api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati.
an5.26:5.2.eng: But the mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

an5.26:5.3.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an5.26:5.3.eng: In whatever way that mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it, they always feel inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma.

an5.26:5.6.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

an5.26:5.7.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

an5.26:5.8.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an5.26:5.9.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ vimuttāyatanaṃ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an5.26:5.9.eng: This is the fourth opportunity for freedom. …

an5.26:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti, nāpi yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati;
an5.26:6.1.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma … nor does the mendicant rehearse the teaching … or think about it.

an5.26:6.2.pli: api ca khvassa aññataraṃ samādhinimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya.
an5.26:6.2.eng: But a meditation subject as a basis of immersion is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

an5.26:6.3.pli: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno aññataraṃ samādhinimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
an5.26:6.3.eng: In whatever way a mendicant’s meditation subject as a basis of immersion is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom, they always feel inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma.

an5.26:6.6.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

an5.26:6.7.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

an5.26:6.8.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an5.26:6.9.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamaṃ vimuttāyatanaṃ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇāti.
an5.26:6.9.eng: This is the fifth opportunity for freedom. …

an5.26:7.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañca vimuttāyatanāni yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti, ananuppattaṃ vā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ anupāpuṇātī”ti.
an5.26:7.1.eng: These are the five opportunities for freedom. If a mendicant stays diligent, keen, and resolute at these times, their mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”
